roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Signing their contracts?
For their benefit.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And their property?
Payable to the head of the family, Mr. Justice Black, for their benefit of course, there being no funds here to get any guardian appointed or being no necessity, their father being alive.
There's no reliance here whatever on that contingent fee agreement, is there?
No.
So we're not talking about --
No, we're not.
Who signed it or who didn't sign it or anything else.
No, it matters not whether there was a contingent fee agreement or not.
I know, we're talking about is the construction of the statute.
That's right.
That was overcome by this statute.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And, that involved whether these children's properties that the Government has provided for them shall be subjected to attorney's fees by reason of a contract made by their father who is not their guardian.
Who was their natural guardian, Mr. Justice Black.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, that's alright.
He was not their legal guardian, was he?
No, sir.
Not in the strict legal sense.
No, Mr. Justice Black.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Gearinger, now that you've answered that, I'd like to get back to your procedure again.
Now, let's suppose this, that you have two men, X and Y, who have the identical disability.
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: They proceed in exactly the same manner before this tribunal.
One of them is married and has three little infant children, like Mr. Hopkins.
The other one is a bachelor.
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The Court hears -- they hear both cases and they both get an identical award.
For some reason rather, they go to the Courts with a lawyer, both are sustained.
Are you clear on what I've said?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, tell me.

What additional work would a lawyer have to do in the case of the man who had a wife and three children to do in order to get that decree over what the man with -- in the case of the man who was a bachelor?
Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.
The amount of legal professional work, undoubtedly, would not be too dissimilar.

They would be almost alike, except if at the hearing examiner's level if he were in -- if he were representing them there, he would of course call upon the wife, the children, the neighbors, or anyone else to appear in that hearing and, herein, testify.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And, testify to what?
They testify as --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: They would have to have that for the other man.
-- and testify as to the state of disability of the head of the family.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, you'd have to have other witnesses for the bachelor just the same whether they were wife and children or not, or it might be a mother and a father, brothers and sisters.
In most cases, Mr. Chief Justice, the hearing is conducted on exhibits of medical reports --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I know.
-- and the hearing and the claimant, so --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I know but the evidentiary, whatever --
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Whatever it is, would the evidentiary requirements be any different in the case of the bachelor or the man with three children?
Not on the substantive question of the disability of the head of family.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Alright.
Now, what in addition to that would they have to prove for the man who had a wife and three children?
The relationship of those dependants to that claimant and their entitlement as his dependants.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Then they would have to ask two questions, one for the wife, “are you the wife?”
And she would say, yes, and you'd have to ask somebody if the children --
Children --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- were his children.
And, that's the only difference?
At the hearing examiner's level, that is the only difference.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Alright.

Now -- but still you are of the opinion that Congress couldn't limit or shouldn't limit the attorney's fees to a percentage of the original claimant himself but, on the other hand, you claim that Congress intended that a lawyer should take up to 25% of everything that comes in to the wife and to these children from the time their legs and arms were happed up until they're 21 years of age.
No, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What do you ask them?

We say this, Your Honor, that because the substantive question of disability is only the head of family claimant and that the benefits flowing to the wife and any dependants he may have, of course, is insulary to a determination of that first substantive question.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
So that, they would have no benefits had he not been found disabled.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Please start off here, don't you, at the statutory provision that limits the base to the amount of past benefits?
That's right, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Actually, what happens here if a lawyer is successful is that Mr. Hopkins is enti-- and his wife and children are entitled not only to pass the sums but to payments in the future.
That is entirely correct, Mr. Justice Fortas.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But the statute provides that the lawyer is confined to the amount that is received before Mr. Hopkins or Mr. Hopkins et al. has by reason of past accruals.
That's entirely correct, Mr. Justice Fortas.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Not only that, then you have a 25% ceiling on that base and then you have the discretion of the Court to cut below that 25%.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is that the way it works?
Yes, Your Honor.
And, in a practical sense, the Court does not in any case or in all cases automatically grant 25%, and he should not.
He should not --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Whether this 25% or not, and whether it is prospective or whether it is retrospective in the percentages that he's entitled to get, why should a man in the case with the wife and three children have to be entitled to get 25% of all of the payments that had been made to the wife and children if all he has to do is ask him if they are the wife or are the children?

Now, don't you think that Congress has a right to say that it shall be limited to that -- to just the claimant himself rather than the other, and don't you think in a case of this kind Congress intended to have a strict application so that these people would not be -- this kind of claimant should not be overborne by lawyer's contracts?
Your Honor, I'm trespassing upon my time, if the Court will allow any longer?

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You can answer the question.
I think that we have concerned ourselves and I apologize for concerning myself so much with the function of this organization and not to the interpretation of the statute.
We submitted to the Court yesterday and, if the Court please, I could now lodge with the Court we reproduced numerous copies of Judge Coleman's opinion that was coming at point from this.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We've heard that draft yesterday.
The --
That --
-- position of -- yes, Your Honor?
That was the unreported opinion --
Yes.
That I asked.
On my happy conscience, Your Honor, if the Court would like to have them lodged with the clerk.

The -- the simple and final position in this case of the Government on one hand, and the petitioner's on the other is that we say that it was the intention of the Congress not to divide and separate bachelors and fathers and mothers since the benefit went to the family unit, and there is no provision in the statute under consideration making such separation.

And, in that connection, the petitioner here in this case relies and urges very respectfully of this Court the position and interpretation taken by Chief Judge Hainsworth in the Fourth Circuit as being the proper interpretation of the statute.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I ask you just one more question.
Yes, Mr. Justice Black.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I haven't yet heard, maybe it's not in the record, it's not yet mentioned, has this man been given payment on the basis of the total permanent incapacity?

Mr. Justice Black, unlike workman's compensation by percentages of permanent disability or non-permanent disability, these -- the benefits provided by the Social Security Act are measured on a formula concerning the payments he has made toward the trust fund and his eligibility by age and earning capacity in the past.
It's automatically computed.
It depends not upon a --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It depends on whether he's injured, doesn't it?
It depends on whether he is disabled.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what disability was found in this case?
In this case, there is -- the Secretary found that he was totally disabled, and payment --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Totally disabled?
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: With hernia?
Under -- and a number of other things, combined together.
In the Secretary's determination, the administrative --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I haven't heard about the other things yet.
Well, we haven't touched upon those, Mr. Justice Black, because the Secretary has decided he was disabled and we have no dispute with that decision.
The Court found he was disabled and we have no dispute with that, so that the solitary question here is upon what base does the district judge fix a percentage fee.
That is the --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I agree with you.
That's the only issue here.
That's the only issue, Mr. Justice.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It would -- we've been going around pretty much.
Yes.
Thank you, Your Honor.
